body:
Hi, the console producer has these options:
--producer-property <producer_prop> A mechanism to pass user-defined 
properties in the form key=value to 
the producer. 
--producer.config <config file> Producer config properties file. Note 
that [producer-property] takes 
precedence over this config.
the console consumer has only
--consumer.config <config file> Consumer config properties file.
IMHO, it would make sense not to add a specific --security-protocol option to them,
but just add a 
--consumer-property <consumer_prop>
to the console consumer

Hi Edoardo,
I will look in to that property, and see I can update that way to be more generic.

But this change has been done for this reason "This will be helpful when running with kerberos. At that time only security.protocol is needed. We can directly mention through command line option."
LGTM.

Thanks for the PR. That's an unfortunate typo. That class is a public class and there is a note:

> NOTE: DO NOT CHANGE EITHER CONFIG NAMES AS THESE ARE PART OF THE PUBLIC API AND CHANGE WILL BREAK USER CODE.

I suggest you keep the old typoed variable (deprecated) and have it point to the new one.
Thanks for the review, merged to trunk and 0.10.0.

@bharatviswa504 I am not saying that the change isn't useful, but I don't think adding a command line option for every config property is a good idea. As the producer already has  CLI mechanism to pass in any property, the same should be done for the consumer

As you said @bharatviswa504, this is only useful with `SASL_PLAINTEXT`, Kerberos mechanism and the default values for all Kerberos settings. `SSL`, `SASL_PLAINTEXT` with the `PLAIN` mechanism and `SASL_SSL` need other configurations anyway and `PLAINTEXT` is the default. As such, the use case seems a bit narrow and I'm not sure it's worth adding a new command-line switch to every tool (which we would want to do to be consistent).
Will be done under KAFKA-3680 addressing both default and configurable classes.
@ijuma could you have a look please? Note this only removes half of the sleep() calls. The other half depend on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3637 which is work in progress.
Review by @gwenshap.

Hi, would you expect this patch to work on Windows?

`assertTrue("log cleaner should have processed up to offset " + firstDirty2, lastCleaned2 >= firstDirty2);`

Errors are:
cleanerTest[0]: "log cleaner should have processed up to offset 597"
cleanerTest[1]: "log cleaner should have processed up to offset 599"
cleanerTest[2]: "log cleaner should have processed up to offset 599"
cleanerTest[3]: "log cleaner should have processed up to offset 599"

@ijuma done.

@SinghAsDev looks mostly good. I would also like for @edenhill to take a pass because we don't currently talk about older brokers and due to brokenness with the forcible connection closing on older brokers, I know the support for this stuff in librdkafka got quite a bit messier. Will wait for him to weigh in.

cc @onurkaraman @guozhangwang 

This patch moves group metadata removal to the periodic offset expiration thread so that group metadata (including the generation) is preserved until all offsets for the group have expired. Since the last member may leave the group before offsets have expired, this patch changes the behavior to increment the generation and essentially write an otherwise empty group metadata object to the log. The main idea is to avoid resetting the generation to 0 until it is safe to do so. This also helps users who currently have no easy way to tell if the group simply doesn't exist or it is dead with possibly some offset state left behind. 

Couple notes on the current patch:
1. I've added a new `Empty` state to the coordinator's group state machine. This may be unnecessary, since it seems `Stable` could work as well, but I preferred slightly to keep the logic for this case separate. It also gets around the need to have a direct transition from `PreparingRebalance` to `Stable`, which should not be possible normally. Instead we allow `PreparingRebalance` to transition to `Empty` when there are no members left in the group.
2. I've done a little bit of additional cleanup. The most notable change is the removal of the offset expiration lock in `GroupMetadataManager`, which seemed unnecessary with a small change to the offset loading logic. Rather than loading offsets directly into the cache, I first stage them in a local collection as is done with the group metadata. This should prevent the expiration thread from seeing stale values, but let me know if I've missed something.
@enothereska : How would code change that uses lambdas for defining aggregators?  Can you show an example here (i.e. not in the Kafka code itself yet as we're still on Java 7 there).
Thanks @gwenshap, I've updated the docs

LGTM, will merge to trunk and 0.10.0 once tests pass. @guozhangwang, if you have additional comments after the latest updates, we can address them in the follow-up PR to remove the other half of hardcoded sleep times.
@miguno Currently this is for Java 7, e.g.,  `.aggregateByKey(new CountLong<>(), "Counts")`. The aggregator has currently two functions and thus it is not ready for lambdas yet.
@ewencp updated the PR. thank you for the review!

Hi this work has been done with @mimaison.

Please note that we had issues with the tests because of 
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3727 
"Consumer.poll() stuck in loop on non-existent topic manually assigned"
and
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3728
If we have to choose one from two, I would prefer optimizing APIs for Java 8 rather than Java 7, i.e. keep two interfaces that have one function each for lambda. But let's discuss about this offline.

EDIT: I see one case is for some external applications to inherit the doc strings; this may be very rare but we'd better be conservative, so nm on my previous comment.
Thank you and LGTM.
Just browsed through the code change, regarding 2) I am still not clear how it prevent concurrent access on the `offsetCache`. Let's discuss offline.
@guozhangwang, yeah, I think we should be strict when it comes to compatibility of API classes that don't have the Unstable annotation. It's hard to explain and understand, otherwise.

https://engineering.linkedin.com/blog/2016/05/kafkaesque-days-at-linkedin--part-1
Review by @gwenshap, cc @mimaison

LGTM, it seems to be following @hachikuji's suggestion on the JIRA. 
Just noticed a couple of minor typos in the code.

Summary of brief offline discussion with @guozhangwang: I think we agree that concurrent loading and expiration is safe with this change, but we are trying to find a way to also solve the problem of expiration with a concurrent offset commit which is unprotected with and without this patch.
hey @hachikuji I'll try to get to this patch after I finish up testing the topic indexing idea you mentioned in the "[DISCUSS] scalability limits in the coordinator" thread.

Because there's only 1 released broker version that supports this API, I think the discussion is a bit premature unless it dives into the expected behavior of 0.9 and 0.8 brokers. Otherwise the only direct use of this API will be once new broker versions / apis are released and clients can maintain backwards compatibility down to 0.10. 

For now, since 0.10 is the most recent broker, backwards compatibility necessarily means 0.8 and 0.9 to users. So I think it is worth documenting here that 0.9 silently ignores the request and 0.8 forcibly drops the connection, or just recommend that the API not be used until 0.11 is released, at which point it can be used to identify 0.11 v. 0.10.

fwiw, kafka-python deals with 0.9 and 0.8 brokers by pipelining two requests in sequence across the same socket: an ApiVersionsRequest followed by a MetadataRequest (v0). 0.10 brokers respond correctly to both requests, 0.9 brokers return a single MetadataResponse causing a correlation id mismatch error, and 0.8 brokers close the socket after the first request and cause the second request to fail (but this is racy -- may require request timeout).

@theduderog that PR was already merged, you should just edit its title. And close this one.
@ijuma Shoot. My bad. Sorry about that.  I was thrown off because github said "Closed with unmerged commits" on the other one.
@theduderog Thanks. Yes, the message is confusing. The reason is that we squash the commits before merging, so GitHub doesn't know the branch was merged.
@ijuma updated

@granthenke @ijuma Should we reconsider this? I hate the ginormous list of ignores, but in practice, we can't rely on people setting up their own global gitignore (we know that from practical experience...). Even if we get the core Kafka devs on board, there are plenty of other contributors and its hard to enforce and easy to miss additions of small files in a review, especially binary files where a diff isn't displayed and so the file is easy to pass over by accident. This particular patch might include a bit more than needed and maybe we could prune some of it down, but in practice we end up adding a lot of non-Kafka-specific stuff like IntelliJ files, etc.
LGTM, really not sure how that managed to creep in there and get past reviews... oops...

Yeah, this is probably one of the more embarrassing mistakes we have :) @ijuma last update seems like it addresses compatibility and cleans things up. LGTM, but do you also want to take a look? I'd suggest also filing a follow up for removing the deprecation and incorrect spelling in a future release -- if we're deprecating, we should also have a plan for removal.

Yes LGTM too. JIRA for removal sounds good. It may make sense to have a general JIRA per release with some pointers instead of one per deprecation. We should actually go through the code and evaluate all deprecations for each release cycle.
I filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3763 to remind us to remove all deprecated APIs before the next major release.
Merged to trunk.
